section.title: Aligner
section.para: Alignment is the process of creating a bilingual translation memory from a pair of already translated monolingual documents. Aligning the contents of the files is a two-step process. First, the files are read by the aligner, which attempts to match the segments that correspond to one another in the original and translated texts. Next, the translator reviews the results and makes any necessary manual adjustments.

The aligner can read all the file formats supported by OmegaT. Select in the menu to access this tool. This brings up the Align Files dialog, where you specify the source and target languages and select the two files you want to align.

note.para: If you have a translation project open, the aligner will automatically use the languages from that project, as well the project-specific segmentation rules, if any.

section.para: Clicking the OK button in theAlign Files dialog brings up the Align window, which shows the results of the automatic alignment.

The main part of the window is divided into three columns:
Keep: The segment pairs in rows that have this check box ticked are saved to the translation memory file. Unticked rows are discarded.
Source: The segments from the original text.
Target: The segments from the translated text.

section.title: Step 1: Adjust alignment parameters
section.para: In this step, the bottom part of the window presents various parameters and options you can change if the initial alignment looks like it could be improved. It also shows an Average score result for the alignement. As a rule of thumb, the lower that score, the more accurate the alignment. Changing a parameter immediately recalculates the alignment, allowing you to quickly try different combinations to obtain the best results.
The available parameters and options are:

listitem.para: Heapwise: This mode compares the documents globally.
Parsewise: This mode compares the documents segment by segment. It is only shown when it is available for the files being aligned.

ID: This mode applies to files consisting of key = value entries. This works even if the order of the keys differ in each file, and when the files have a different number of entries. It is only shown when both selected files are recognized as key=value files.
Viterbi: The default algorithms used to align the documents.
Forward-Backward: An alternative algorithm that can be used to align the documents.
There is no hard and fast rule on which algorithm is better. Try both, and use the one that yields the better results for your files.

section.para: Click Continue to proceed to the next step.

section.title: Step 2: Make manual corrections
section.para: Manual adjustments are generally required after the initial automatic alignment process.
The manual step window presents the original and translated text in the source and target columns, respectively.
To align a source and target segment found in different rows:

listitem.para: Press the space bar (the shortcut for EditStart Pinpoint Align).
Click on the corresponding segment in the other column.

section.para: After repeating the process a few times, press Cr (or select EditRealign pending )to update the alignment of the remaining segments.
To move one or more segments individually, select them and press U or D (or click the Move Up or Move Down button).
Only rows with the Keep box ticked in the first column are saved to the translation memory.
After you finish aligning the two columns, click Save TMX... to create the translation memory.
